document.text: Your 4-H Club -Rally will be held at Appomattox September 4th. The meeting will begin with a parade, starting ifrom the auditorium promptly at 1030. Every Club member is expected to attend, and make this parade as large and attractive as pos- siple. The County Agent and 4-H Club members of Prince Edward  have been invited to be with us. After the parade there will be a program in the auditorium songs, yells, and reports from each Club, district short course, and state short course. Mr. Montgomery, State Boys Club Agfent, and Mr. J. A. Burke, School Supt. will be the principle speakers. A picnic dinner will be spread on the grounds. The afternoon program will conclude Vesper Services then a picnic supper will be served, after which there will be games and stunts till 745. Moving pictures 8 p m., all club members will be charged admission fee of only ten cents. The public is cordially invited come, bring your friends and ask them to help you enjoy the day by bringing a basket of lunch. _

document.text: with her sister, Mrs. B. C. Sims. Otis Sims spent last week end with his grandmother. -------- o------------ The fifth Sunday institute of the Appomattox circuit was That the Appomattox county School Board at its regular meeting at Appomattox, at of flee of Div. Supt., Wednesday, June 8, at 1000 A. M., will re ceive bids for a school bus to run from a point one mile be yond the present Bent Creek white schoolhouse, on Rt. 13, by Bent Creek to Oakville, on Route 306. The bus body must be a standard, closed top with a capacity from 25 to 85 chil dren. Contract to run for two years. The contractor is to pay two-thirds of cost of lia bility insurance. J. A. Burke, Snpt.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. G OBrien, S L. Ferguson, Jr., J. H. OBrien, W. B. Caldyell, F. L. Murphy, E. VR-y Smith, Andrew Wingfield, H. C. Pul iam, Uoel Flood, Don Moses, John T. Cole, J. W. Caw son, John A. Iweedy, R. W. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: who have been spending some time with Mrs. James B. Abbitt, left to day toiin. Lt. McKee in New Or leans. Marvin Godsey, of Culpeper vis ited his mother, Mrs. A. F. Godsey Tuesday. Mr. and Mrs. Homer Blackwell and family, who have been liying in Norfolk have moved back to Appo mattox and are occupying the resi dence formerly occupied by Mrs. Berta Smith. Miss Dorothy Ould, who has been visiting Miss Betty Parriott, of- Farmville, has returned to the home of her grandmother, Mrs. W.L.Ould. Mrs. Oscar Moss and daughter Nancy, are visiting in the home of Mrs. J. E. Sears. Dan .Browning, of Richmond, was a recent guest of Mrs. R. N. Dawson. Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Bradley, of Richmon spent Sunday with Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Mann. Mrs. G. L. Doss and daughter, LeFern, who have been visiting re- latives here and in Lynchburg, re turned to their home in Portsmouth Tuesday. They were accompanied I by Miss Barbara Ann Johnson. Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Burke, Jr. of Richmond spent the week-end here.

document.text: which he used in the F. F. A. Pub lic Speaking Contest and which he presented to the banquet group. Fol lowing his talk, Bobby was awarded an F. F. A. Foundation Award for Public Speaking by Mr. H. B. Pack. Other awards made by Mr. Pack were a Farm Mechanics and a Farm Electrification award, both presented to Claude Allen Moore for outstand ing work along those lines. Mr. J. A. Burke, Superintendent of Schools of Appomattox County, reported to the group on his exper iences at the National F. F. A. Con vention which he attended in Kan sas City last October.

document.text: Well, that V awaited tournament gcr match be- tween Col. Flotad and J. A. Burke has become history since yesterday afternoon, and on the worthy locks of the lat ter repose the laurels of vic tory. That settles for awhile a very old argument. All of us here know that Don MoSes is one of the best- all-round men any county ever had. Hes showing con stantly his ability and versatil ity. Frixmple, last Wednes day night Rev. Thompson was away at the encampment and at prayer meeting the schedul ed leader failed to appear, and impromp uly thats a good word isnt it? Don arose to the occasion and gave a mas terful talk on two chapters from Haggai. One of the dea cons declared it,the best pray er meeting talk hed ever heard. Yes sir, Don s a gifted fellow.    Father Darkleaf has blush es that have never been blush ed, but he shed one of them Monday when a lady Man teo said, Are you Father Darkleaf? Why I figured that youd, have long whiskers. - ---- - ----- -o- ----  ----- - M arket Report

document.text: Welcome Home from the Open Road, was the theme of the 5th year Reunion of the 1 46 Gradua ting Class of the Appomattox High School, held on Saturday evening, June 2, in the high school cafeteria A reunion dinner featured the oc casioin. Gypsy music and decorations were carried out for the class theme, The Open Road. The class colors of red and white dominated the room with a background of pines with tent and campfire. Mrs. Mary Spiggre Hudson, vice president of the class, served as toastmistress in the absence of the president, Garland H. Reynolds, who is now serving in the Navy. The toastmistress acknowledged a vacant chair at the head of the table stating, This is in remem brance of our beloved chieftan principal L. Crawley, who has pass ed on higher camping ground. Guests for the evening other than class members included J. A. Burke, superintendent of schools Mrs. J, A. Burke, and Miss Harriett Holley and Mrs. W. M. Morris, class spon sors. Topics of interest to the class members were reviewed as follows Class history, Nellwyn OBrien Class prophecy, Nell Williamson Cabaniss Class mirror, Ann Housman, sec retary of class Last will and testament, Alice Jennings Layne, class treasurer. To the mothers of the tribe the toastmistress presented earrings to bind them and the class closer to gether. The roll was called by the sponsors and each member present answered, giving a brief review if his or her experience on the open road during the past five years. Class members present included

document.text: weeks now Slates of delegates to district and state conventions were elected at a Democratic mass meeting last Fri day night at the court house. The meeting adopted two resolutions one endorsing Watkins M. Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. Smith. Congressman W. M. Abbitt was present and addressed the meeting. Charles F. P. Crawley served as the presiding officer of the meeting and C. W. Smith served as secretary. The following delegates, instruct ed to vote as a unit, were named to the Fourth District Convention in Petersburg, May 24 J. A. Bingham, George Abbitt, Jr. G. T. Moses, Sr. G. B. Buchanan, J. H. OBrien, Wal lace E. Bondurant, John E. Burnett, Mrs. N. A. Wagers, N. E. Farrar, C. C. Harvey, Mrs. J. W. Flood, Mrs. Hazel R. Mann, Grover E. Smith, E. T. Guill, C. T. Moses, Jr. H. C. Pulliam, Mrs. Margaret Calcott, R. C. Hubbard, P. B. Stratton, Calvin H. Robinson, J. A. Burke, D. A. Conner, J. W. Cawthorn, F. J. Smith, Irby B. Wheeler, David T. Robertson, Chas. F. P. Crawley, T. C. Ligon, W. W. OBrien, Mrs! C. H. Robinson, Mrs. F. C. Dresser, J. W. Conner, Tobey E. Inge, Eula M. Burke, R. D. Robinson, W. D. Fer guson, H. A. Williams and John P.

document.text: week end with his family. Mrs. R. E. Harris, Mr. Jesse and Melvin Harris and Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Harris, Jr. are camping on Staunton River. Rev. E. W. Terry of Evergreen Baptist Church is having a meeting this week in Kentucky. The Evergreen Ruritans held their regular meeting last Thursday night at the com- mur ity center. Sympathy is extended to the family of Mr. J. A. Burke who was buried Sunday. We are sorry to hear of Mrs. Ruth Clapp breaking her arm in a fall. She is at her daughters, Mrs. Alice Martin. The pastor and deacons and their wives of Evergreen Baptist Church enjoyed supper at the Parkway Restaurant Saturday night. Mr. and Mrs. Wylie Richard son and Mr. Garland Mayberry of Lynchburg was dinner guests of Mrs. Mott Harvey Sunday. Mrs. H. D. Baker and Mrs. David Paulette called in the same home. There will be a call meeting of the Evergreen Cemetery Organization on Tuesday night October 1, 1974 at the community house. Please all members be present and members of Methodist and Baptist Church. Tins meeting will be at 730 p.m. . FMAg and Mrs. Jimmy Wo-

document.text: Wednesday evening at eight oclock, at Liberty Baptist church, addresses were made and a social observed ip honor of Miss E. V. Hardy, who has tendered her resignation as a teacher in toe local.high school. The program of t h e evening consisted of a tribute to Miss Hardy from her pastor the Rev. W. M. Thompson, and a tribute as a teacher by J. A. Burke, Superintendent of schools in the county. For a number of years Miss Hardy, has taught a group of young women in toe Sunday school, trainiiig, them to become teachers. The sup erintendent of  the  Srififfay school, Don Mqses, spoke with feeling of the splendid servicer rendered by her in this depart ment. Varioris persons present indulged in interesting remin iscences of by-gone days, Miss Hardy having been a member of-Liberty church for a num ber of years.  , ------- -------- o -----  ------ MANNREYNOLDS
